title: 106_s856
content: The "Expanded Options in Higher Education for District of Columbia Students Act of 1999" establishes a program to provide college-bound residents of the District of Columbia with more choices among institutions of higher education. The "Expanded Options in Higher Education for District of Columbia Students Act of 1999" provides grants to eligible institutions to cover the difference in tuition for in-state and out-of-state students. If funds are insufficient, grants will be reduced proportionally and increased if more funds become available. In this section, definitions for "academic year" and "eligible student" are provided. An eligible student must be a resident of the District of Columbia for at least 12 consecutive months, have income below a certain level, and start their undergraduate course. An eligible student must begin their undergraduate course within 3 years of graduating from secondary school and be enrolled at least half-time in a program leading to a recognized educational credential at an eligible institution. An eligible student must be enrolled at least half-time in a program leading to a recognized educational credential at an eligible institution in Maryland or Virginia, maintain satisfactory progress, not have completed their first undergraduate baccalaureate course, and file an application with the institution. Virginia is an institution of higher education eligible for student financial assistance programs under title IV of the Higher Education Act of 1965. The term "secondary school" is defined under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. The Secretary refers to the Secretary of Education. Nothing in this Act requires a higher education institution to make changes. The Secretary may enter into agreements with public or private entities to administer the tuition payment program for eligible students. The application process for tuition assistance must be followed as required by the eligible institution. The Secretary, in consultation with eligible institutions, develops policies and procedures for the program. The Secretary reports annually to Congress on student attendance, grant awards, tuition payments, and academic progress. Authorization of appropriations is provided. Authorization of Appropriations: $20,000,000 for fiscal year 2000 and necessary sums for 5 succeeding years. Funds available until expended. Effective Date: Academic years starting on or after July 1, 2000. The Secretary of Education may provide financial assistance to the University of the District of Columbia for authorized activities under the Higher Education Act. $1,500,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2000, with additional funding for the following 5 years. The Secretary may award grants to eligible institutions to pay tuition and fees for eligible students, up to $2,000 per academic year. Grant amounts are determined based on the number of eligible students and available funds. The Secretary prorates grant awards for students attending school part-time. Definitions include "eligible student" meeting specific requirements and "eligible institution" being a private or proprietary institution of higher education in DC or adjacent counties. The Secretary defines an eligible institution as one that offers a 2-year or 4-year program leading to an associate or baccalaureate degree, is located in DC or adjacent counties, participates in student financial assistance programs, and agrees to specified conditions. The Secretary of Education defines an eligible institution as one offering a 2-year or 4-year program leading to an associate or baccalaureate degree, located in DC or adjacent counties, participating in student financial assistance programs, and agreeing to specified conditions. Eligible students must submit an application for tuition and fee payment to the institution. The Secretary administers the program in consultation with the Mayor of DC and may delegate administration to another entity if more efficient. Authorization of Appropriations: The Secretary, in consultation with eligible institutions, will develop policies and procedures for the program. $10,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2000, with additional funding for the following years. The program will be effective for academic years starting on or after July 1, 2000.
